Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: Deputy minister, what do you believe is behind this recent increase in terrorist bombings?

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: Bad sportsmanship. A ruthless minority of people seems to have forgotten certain good old fashioned virtues. They just can't stand seeing the other fellow win. If these people would just play the game, instead of standing on the touch line heckling -

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: In fact, killing people -

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: - In fact, killing people - they'd get a lot more out of life.

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: Mr. HELPMANN, what would you say to those critics who maintain that the Ministry Of Information has become too large and unwieldy ...?

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: David ... in a free society information is the name of the game. You can't win the game if you're a man short.

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: And the cost of it all, Deputy Minister? Seven percent of the gross national produce ...

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: I understand this concern on behalf of the tax-payers. People want value for money and a cost-effective service.

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: That is why we always insist on the principle of Information Retrieval Charges. These terrorists are not pulling their weight, and it's absolutely right and fair that those found guilty should pay for their periods of detention and the Information Retrieval Procedures used in their interrogation.

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: Do you think that the government is winning the battle against terrorists?

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: On yes. Our morale is much higher than theirs, we're fielding all their strokes, running a lot of them out, and pretty consistently knocking them for six. I'd say they're nearly out of the game.

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: But the bombing campaign is now in its thirteenth year ...

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: Beginner's luck.

Speaker: interviewer
Dialogue: Thank you very much, Deputy Minister.

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: Thank you, David ... and a very merry Christmas to you all.

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: There, that's enough for tonight. He won't come Xmas Eve if you don't get plenty of sleep.

Speaker: girl buttle
Dialogue: Father Christmas can't come if we haven't got a chimney.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: You'll see.

Speaker: girl buttle
Dialogue: How will he get down from upstairs?

Speaker: boy buttle
Dialogue: It's a secret.

Speaker: girl buttle
Dialogue: You've come ...

Speaker: official
Dialogue: I hereby inform you under powers entrusted to me under Section 47, Paragraph 7 of Council Order Number 438476, that Mr Buttle, Archibald, residing at 412 North Tower, Shangri La Towers, has been invited to assist the Ministry of Information with certain enquiries, the nature of which may be ascertained on completion of application form BZ/ST/486/C fourteen days within this date, and that he is liable to certain obligations as specified in Council Order 173497, including financial restitutions which may or may not be incurred if Information Retrieval procedures beyond those incorporated in Article 7 subsections 8, 10 & 32 are required to elicit information leading to permanent arrest - notification of which will he served with the time period of 5 working days as stipulated by law. In that instance the detainee will be debited without further notice through central banking procedures without prejudice until and unless at such a time when re-imbursement procedures may be instituted by you or third parties on completion of a re-imbursement form RB/CZ/907/X ...

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Sign here please.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: What? where have you taken him?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Press harder his time. Good.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: What is this all about?

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Mrs Buttle, are you alright?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Eh! Eh! Eh! We're Department of Works! Department of Works up here! Careful with those bloody things!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Don't take any notice, love, it's their training makes them like animals. Best in the world, though.

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Don't you worry love, we'll have everything shipshape in a jiffy.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's it. Nothing to worry about.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's Buttle downstairs who can worry, eh?

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: There must be some mistake ... Mr Buttle's harmless...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: We don't make mistakes.

Speaker: mr kurtzman
Dialogue: Does anyone know where Lowry is?

Speaker: mr kurtzman
Dialogue: Where the hell is Sam Lowry?!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hello ... What ... what? Oh ... Mr Kurtzman! ... You're up late. Oh, is it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: The electronics here are up the spout. Yours too, sir? Don't worry sir - I'll be there.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sam!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Jack!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Long time no see!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Well, since you disappeared up the ladder of Information Retrieval ... I don't expect to see you slumming in Records - what's the problem?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Problem? - No problem - yes, everything's going fantastically well, wonderful, marvelous, great career prospects, Alison in great shape, kids fine, beautiful home, I'm on Security Level Five now, and Mr Helpmann relies on me more and more, yes, couldn't be better, I feel terrifically motivated and job- rewarded -

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You sound worried.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Me? - if I'm worried about anyone, it's you. What happened to you, Sam? You were the brightest of us -

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sorry. Nothing.  See you - I'm going to be late.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You are late.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Even later.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sam, your life is going wrong - let your friends tell you - Records is a dead end department, no Security Level worth a damn, it's impossible to get noticed -

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes, I know, fantastic, marvellous, wonderful - remember me to Alison - and the - er - twins.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Triplets.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Really? - God, how time flies!

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: I want to report a wrongful arrest.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: You want Information Adjustments. Different department.

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: I've been to Information Adjustments. They sent me here. They told me you had a form I had to fill in.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Have you got an Arrest Receipt?

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Is it stamped?

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Stamped?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: No, there's no stamp on it. You see! I can't give you the form until it's stamped.

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Where do I get it stamped?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Information Adjustments.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Perhaps the machine's on the blink! It keeps picking up old films. That can't he right, can it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's not the machine. There's a mismatch on the personnel code numbers... Ah there we go! That's a B58/732 when it should be a T47/215 ... Tuttle ... he should have 31.06, debited against his account for electrical procedures, not Buttle.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Oh my God, a mistake!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's not our mistake!

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Isn't it? Whose is it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Information Retrieval.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Oh, good!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Expediting has put in for electrical procedures in respect of Buttle, Archibald, shoe repair operative, but Security has invoiced Admin for Tuttle, Archibald, heating engineer

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: What a relief! I don't know what I'd do if you ever got promoted.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't worry.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: But if they did promote you

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I've told you before. I'd turn it down.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Would you really, Sam?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Really.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: You've been promoted.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: It's your mother isn't it? Pulling strings again.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What a BITCH!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Now, when you come in tomorrow, Mrs Lowry, we'll make a little tuck here ... and there ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I just wish you would stop interfering, mother! I don't want promotion. I'm happy where I am.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: No you're not. Jack Lint is a lesson to you - he never had your brains but he's got the ambition. You haven't got the ambition but luckily you've got me. And Mr Helpmann. Mr Helpmann was very close -

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Now, Mrs Lowry, don't get upset  Please wait in reception, Mr Lowry, you're giving her wrinkles.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You see!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Now Mrs Lowry, try to relax. You must trust me. I'll make you twenty years younger ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Huh!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: ... twenty-five if we just drain the excess fluid from the pouches ...

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Dr Jaffe, you're a genius. Would you like to be Surgeon General? Four Star. I know everybody.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Well they won't know you when I've finished with you.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: First we must eliminate the excess derma ... so! ... Then the flaccid tissues under the eyes ... And now the forehead ... Zip! I lift the wrinkles and worry lines right up into the wi- into the hairline, comme ca ...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: And now the template ... There ... there ... there ... Now a bit of sticky ... There we go!  Already she is twice as beautiful as she was before - voila!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: My God, it works.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Mr Helpmann was very close to your poor father. He was very close to me. Still is. He'll take you under his wing at Information Retrieval. You'll like it when you get there.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You're not listening, mother.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: It's a present for my son.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I hope you like it. It's very exclusive.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: It's something for executives.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Hello, Spiro. Merry Christmas.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: I'm sorry but ...

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You remember Samuel, my son.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: {suddenly unctious) Oh, but of course ...

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: We're meeting Mrs Terrain.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Are we?

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Ah yes, the lady is waiting.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mother, I thought we were going to be able to talk .... Oh God, she's got what's he name with her.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Ida! Sam!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Alma, how are you? You're looking wonderful! Hello, Shirley.

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Salt?

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Happy Christmas, Sam.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Sorry we're late. Shall we order? Get it out of the way. What are you going to have Alma?

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: I can't make up my mind whether to have a number one or a number two. What do you recommend, Spiro?

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Between you and me, Madam, today the number two.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Thank you, Spiro. Shirley, what are you going to have?

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Between you and me, Mademoiselle, today the number one. Madam Lowry?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Oh, to hell with the diet, a number eight, please.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: A most perceptive choice, Madam, if I may say so.  Monsieur?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mother, I need to ...

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Monsieur. Quel numero.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I don't know which numero.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Numero, trois.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: you've started your treatment.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: You noticed.  I must tell you all about it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mother, will you listen to

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: It's too exciting. I've left Dr Jaffe and gone to Dr. Chapman.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Numero deux, duck a l'orange.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: The acid man?

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Really, Ida, just because his techniques are revolutionary ... I don't go around calling Dr Jaffe the knife man.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Numero une, crevettes  la mayonaaise.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I'm sorry Alma, I didn't mean to sound so ...

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: That's all right Ida ... it's just that he's such an artist. To him, cutting is so crude ... so primitive.

Speaker: spiro
Dialogue: Numero trois, steak.  Monsieur, Mesdames, Bon appetit.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Acid on the other hand, can be used for such wonderfully subtle shading, such delicate nuances - just like a Rembrant etching ... and it's so much quicker. Why, if it weren't for a teensy-weensy complication - the doctor said it could have happened to anyone - I would have had these bandages off yesterday.

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Salt?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: What were we saying?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: This isn't rare!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: By the way, I saw a wonderful idea for Christmas presents at the chemists. Gift tokens. Medical gift tokens.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Oh, that sounds marvellous.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Yes, they're good at any doctor's and at many of the major hospitals - and they're accepted for gynecological complications including Caesarian section.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look - please - I'm sorry - but honestly, mother, this is -

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Really, Sam - when are you going to do something about these terrorists?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What? Now? It's my lunch hour.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Actually, Alma, that's one of the little things I was dying to tell you ... Sam's been promoted to Information Retrieval.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mother!

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Oh that's wonderful! Congratulations Sam...

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: You can show those fucking murderous bastards a thing or two.

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: Shirley!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Stop this!  If I want you to stick your oar in, mother, I'll tell you where to stick it!

Speaker: shirley
Dialogue: Pepper...?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look - I've got to get back -

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Sam ... you haven't had dessert.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I don' t want dessert. I don't want promotion. I don't want anything.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Don't be childish, Samuel. Of course you want something. You must have hopes, wishes, dreams.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: NO, NOTHING. NOT EVEN DREAMS!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm taking you to a safe place. A place where they will never be able to get at us ... ever.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: There's no way they can approach us without being seen. You're safe here.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hello - Central Services - I'm at 579B Block l9, Northwestern Section D - that's exit 1 on Green Pastures Highway at the Orange Blossom Flyover - and I've got trouble with the air- conditioning

Speaker: phone voice
Dialogue: Thank you or calling Central Services. am sorry, due to temporary staff shortage, Central Services cannot take service calls centrally between 2300 and 0900 hours - have a nice day - this has not been a recording, incident-

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: This is an emergency!

Speaker: phone voice
Dialogue: Thank you for calling Central Services. I am sorry, due -

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes, but. I've got to have a heating engineer

Speaker: phone voice
Dialogue: Thank you for calling Cen -

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: Ah ha ... there you are, Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What? How do you know my name?

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: We know everything here. This is the Storeroom of Knowledge.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Then perhaps you can help me. I've lost someone who ...

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: We know that too. You've come to the right place.

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: Oh, yes. We've got everything here. Every bit of knowledge, wisdom, learning ... every experience, every thought neatly filed away.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What? You mean you've got ...

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: Well not exactly. But, if you help us we'll help you. The Forces Of Darkness have won the day ... but, tomorrow is another one

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What do I have to do.

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: You must save the day.

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: This is the Sword Of Truth ... and this the Helmet Of Justice.

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: And this. completes the outfit.

Speaker: gent
Dialogue: It won't be pleasant but, trust me.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hello ... hello ...

Speaker: phone voice
Dialogue: Hello. Mr Lowry?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: phone voice
Dialogue: Put the phone down and your hands up.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What? Who is this?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Nice and easy now. Keep your hands where I can see them.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What is this?  Who the hell are you?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Harry Tuttle. Heating engineer. At your service.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Tuttle! Are you from Central Services?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Ha!!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: But ... I called Central Services.

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: They're a bit overworked these days. Luckily I intercepted your call.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Wait a minute, what was that business with the gun?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: A little precaution, sir. I've had traps set for me before now. There are people in Central Services who'd love to get their hands on Harry Tuttle.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Are you saying this is illegal?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Well, yes ... and no. Officially, only Central Service operatives are supposed to touch this stuff ... Could you hold these.

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: ... Mind you, if ever they could prove I'd been working on their equipment ... well, that's a different matter ... up a bit with the torch, sir.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sorry. wouldn't it be easier just to work for Central Services?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Couldn't stand the pa - ah - we're getting warm -

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: The pace?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: The paperwork, couldn't stand the paperwork.  Over to the left please, if you don't mind sir. Hold it there. Yes, there's more bits of paper in Central Services than bits of pipe - read this, fill in that, hand in the other - listen, this old system of yours could be on fire and I couldn't even turn on the kitchen tap without filling in a 27B/6.... Bloody paperwork.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Well I suppose one has to expect a certain amount

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Why? I came into this game for adventure - go anywhere, travel light, get in, get out, wherever there's trouble, a man alone. Now they've got the whole country sectioned of and you can't move without a form. I'm the last of a breed. Ah ha! Found it!  There's your problem.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Can you fix it?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: No. But I can bypass it with one of these

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Are you expecting anyone?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No. Wait here.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Central Services.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...ervices.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Uh - what? - I ...

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: You telephone, sir.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...elephoned sir.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Trouble with your air-conditioning.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...ditioning.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No, not at all. I mean, it's all right. It's fixed.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Fixed?

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: Fixed?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I mean it fixed itself.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Fixed itself.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...ixed itself.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Machines don't fix themselves.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ... fix themselves.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: He's tampered with it, Dowser.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...ampered. with it, Spoor.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look, I'm sorry about your wasted journey

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: I think we'd better have a look.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ... have a look.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No you can't.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Just a minute!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Have you got a 27B/6?

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Now look what you've done to him.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Have you got one or haven't you?

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: Not ... as such ...

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: But we can get one.

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: It's all right, Terry, it's all right, everything's all right.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but I'm a bit of a stickler for paper work. Where would we be if we didn't follow the correct procedures?

Speaker: spoor
Dialogue: We'll be back.

Speaker: dowser
Dialogue: ...Be back.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Thanks, Lowry, you're a good man in a tight corner.  TUTTLE returns to work, fitting in the new by-pass gadget and tightening the nuts, and happily humming "BRAZIL".

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Listen .. um ... I don't want to get involved in any of this. But I work at the Ministry of Information, and I happen to know that Information Retrieval have been looking for an Archibald Tuttle, Heating Engineer. You wouldn't by any chance be -

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: My friends call me Harry. Information Retrieval, eh? Interesting!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What do they want you or?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: Time to go.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Thank you very much. How much will it...?

Speaker: tuttle
Dialogue: On the house. You did me a favor. Check the corridor.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: All clear.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hey that's a dead end.

Speaker: neighbour
Dialogue: I think Kurtzman getting is suspicious.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What have we got on today?

Speaker: neighbour
Dialogue: Casablanca.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Mr Lowry! Would you step in here a moment please.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Thank God you're here! We're in terrible trouble! Look at this! Look at this!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: A cheque.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: The refund for Tuttle!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Tuttle?

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: I mean, Buttle! It's been confusion from the word go! He's been wrongly charged for Electromemorytherapy and someone somewhere is trying to make us carry the can!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I've never seen a Ministry cheque before.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: We've got to get rid of it! There's been a balls-up somewhere, and when the music stops they'll jump on whoever's holding the cheque!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Send it to somebody else. Send it to Buttle. It's his cheque.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: I've tried that! Population Census have got him down as dormanted, the Central Collective Storehouse computer has got him down as deleted, and the Information Retrieval have got him down as inoperative ... Security has him down as excised., Admin have him down as completed

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hang on.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He is dead.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Dead! Oh no! That's terrible! We'll never get rid of the damned thing! What are we going to do?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Try next of kin.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Next of kin!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: There we go. Mrs. Veronica Buttle. What's the number on the cheque?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Into memory. Now ... Central Banking ... Buttle, Veronica ... Deposit

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Please don't come back! Please don't come back!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Problem. She doesn't have a bank account.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Perhaps we can lose it ... behind the filing cabinet ... or destroy it ... burn it ... eat it ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You'd never get away with it. Besides, you can't do that to somebody's refund. It's Christmas. There is one more option.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Drive out to Mrs Buttle, give her the cheque, tell her to sign her name on the back, cash it at the corner sweet shop.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: That's brilliant!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'll do it for you. Authorise the cheque. What's the address?

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Here. What do I do next?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Call the motor pool and authorise personal transport.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Of course, of course. Leave it to me. How do I authorize a cheque?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Here we are. Pink and blue receipts. All you've got to do is sign these and the back of the cheque.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: Oh God! I think I've broken a bone. What a pathetic thing I am.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That's it.

Speaker: kurtzman
Dialogue: You are good to me Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't mention it. See you later.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Excuse me. Can you tell me ...

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Eff off.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mrs Buttle

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Mrs Buttle ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Are you Mrs Buttle?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: My name is Lowry - Sam Lowry. I'm from the Ministry of Information.  I've come to give you a cheque.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's a refund ... I'm afraid there was a mistake.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: Mistake?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes. Not my department ... I'm only records. It seems that Mr Buttle was overcharged by Information Retrieval. I don't think they usually make mistakes ... but, er ... I suppose we're all human.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: My husband's dead, isn't he?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Er ... I assure you Mrs Buttle, the Ministry is always very scrupulous about following up and eradicating error. If you have any complaints which you'd like to make, I'd be more than happy to send you the appropriate forms.

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: What have you done with his body?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Um ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look, I'm very sorry, but I'm afraid I don't know anything about it ... I'm really just delivering the cheque. Er ... If you wouldn't mind signing these receipts  I'll go and leave you in peace.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Uh ...

Speaker: mrs buttle
Dialogue: He hadn't done anything ... He was good ... What have you done with his body?

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Are you alright?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's you ... it's you ...

Speaker: jill
Dialogue: Mrs Buttle, are you alright?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Wait! Stop! Come back!!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Girl ... fair hair ...

Dialogue: ...sabotage!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I want to talk to him.

Dialogue: Actually, I've decided ...

Speaker: mother

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Congratulations ...

Dialogue: Chirst yes, you've seen her with her clothes off. Faces are a doddle compared to tits and arse.  No hairline.

Dialogue: Really, Louis.

Dialogue: Excuse me, Dr Chapman, did you say something?

Dialogue: Now see here, Chapman. At least mine don't look like they've been mugged.

Dialogue: Sam!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Whatever happened to you?

Dialogue: There was a slight complication. Dr. Chapman says it often happens with a delicate skin like mine. Nothing to worry about. He's promised me I'll have these bandages off in a ...

Dialogue: Actually, there's someone I want to meet ...

Speaker: mrs terrain
Dialogue: I know, I know ...!

Dialogue: Can I get you a drink, Shirley?

Dialogue: You remember Alison?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: {winking at Sam) She doesn't like me telling anyone but she's pleased as anything really.

Dialogue: Er, I knew you looked different.

Dialogue: Remember how they used to stick out?

Dialogue: What? - Oh, yes - vividly. I used to wonder if they were real.

Dialogue: What, my ears?

Dialogue: Your ears?

Dialogue: Dr. Jaffe has pinned her ears back.

Dialogue: You remember my wife ... Alis -

Dialogue: Of course .... of course ... Come on Alison - Barbara

Dialogue: Well, I ...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sorry ...

Dialogue: Your father and I were very close. Of course Jeremiah was senior to me but we were close friends ... especially after the bombing  keep his name alive at the office every day.

Speaker: helpmann
Dialogue: It's as though he's there speaking to me - "'ere I am, J.H.!" The ghost in the machine.

Dialogue: Hello.

Dialogue: No, you can't have any more chairs! There's only one left in here now, and I need that to sit on!  Oh ... er, sorry. Who are you?

Dialogue: Sam Lowry.

Dialogue: My name's Lime. Harvey Lime. Welcome to Expediting.

Dialogue: Ah.  Would you mind if I borrowed your computer console?

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: You want to take my console into your office?

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: Alright. There's someone I want to check out. A woman called Gillian Layton.

Dialogue: A woman eh? I see.

Dialogue: I know her age and distinguishing marks. But I need an address or a place of work or something

Dialogue: This is your dream girl, is it?

Dialogue: Look, let me use the console for a few minutes.

Dialogue: When there's a woman involved - there's no stopping me. Now, let me have that sheet.

Dialogue: Sod it, it's broken!

Dialogue: You haven't switched it on.

Dialogue: Oh - yes. Look you're putting me off, standing there! Go back to your office and I'll give you a knock when I've finished.

Dialogue: Go on. I'm not going to elope with her.

Speaker: lime
Dialogue: Computers are my forte.

Dialogue: Ah, Lowry, glad I caught you ...  No, send it back for ... Are you settling down? ... I want this order rescinded ... Anyway, tidy it up, Lowry, there's a good chap - get a new suit. Did you want the lift?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Thanks. Are you officer 412/L?

Dialogue: For my sins. Are you settling in alright?

Dialogue: Yes, thanks.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Terrific. I'm really glad you dropped by. Unfortunately, I don't have any time right now I've got a queue of customers to deal with - er, why don't we have a drink tonight?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Ah ...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I don't want to take up your time now, but I was hoping you could give me some information on somebody. It's a security level three matter and Information Retrieval records says to refer to you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: OK. Come back this afternoon, about four o'clock. If you give me the number of the case, I'll have the dossier here waiting.  My tailor,... well worth the investment.

Dialogue: I've got numbers all over these - I'm not sure which is the one you want.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Layton! Oh shit!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You clever bastard! I might have guessed. You only moved in today and you're already hot on the bloody trail.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Am I?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Please, Sam, we're going to have to be open to each other on this one. If you make a reputation with this case, it'll be at my expense.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: How much do you know?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Not much.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Enough though, eh?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Not really, no.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: OK. OK. Let's not fence around ... This is the situation. Some idiot somewhere in the building, some insect, confused two of our clients,

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: B58/732, that's A. Buttle isn't it?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Christ! You do know it all!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No, no, I don't. I'm just beginning Honestly. Sorry, carry on.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, your A. Buttle has been confused with T47/215, an A. Tuttle. I mean, it's a joke! Somebody should be shot for that. So B58/732 was pulled in by mistake.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You got the wrong man.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I did not get the wrong man. I got the right man. The wrong man was delivered to me as the right man! I accepted him, on trust, as the right man. Was I wrong? Anyway, to add to the confusion, he died on us. Which, had he been the right man, he wouldn't have done.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You killed him?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sam, there are very rigid parameters laid down to avoid that event but Buttle's heart condition did not appear on Tuttle's file. Don't think I'm dismissing this business, Sam. I've lost a week's sleep over it already.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm sure you have

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: There are some real bastards in this department who don't mind breaking a few eggs to make an omelette, but thank God there are the new boys like me who want to maintain decent civilized standards of terrorist eradication. We've got the upper hand for the moment, but they're waiting for us to slip up, and a little slip- up like this is just the chance they're looking for.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: So how ...?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What I've got to do now is pick up Tuttle, interrogate him at the same voltage as Buttle, to the same meter reading to the last penny, and juggle the books in electrical banking.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What has Tuttle done?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We suspect him of freelance subversion.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He's a freelance subversive?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: He's a compulsive heating engineer. A maverick ex-Central Service repair man with a grudge against society. Now, fortunately, we're nearly out of the wood, I think. At least we will be when I get this Layton woman under arrest.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What's she done?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You didn't know as much about this business as you pretended to, did you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Er ... no.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Very smart.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Er ... but I would've found out anyway.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yes. I'm impressed.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Tell me about Layton.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: She witnessed the Tuttle arrest - the Buttle arrest - and since then she's been making wild allegations, obviously trying to exploit the situation - she's working for somebody, and she's not working for us.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: A terrorist?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Ah ... thanks.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: But surely, I mean, perhaps she just happened to live above the Buttles, and ...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Look after that suit, eh. Barbara chose it for me.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Right. Er, you're not going to keep calling her Barbara, are you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Barbara's a perfectly good name, isn't it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look, about the Layton woman - maybe she's just trying to help the Buttle family.

Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Why? Hell, not for any reason ...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: {baffled) I don't follow you.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Out of kindness.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Kindness? What's the purpose behind this line of enquiry?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: So what are you going to do about her?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Get her out of circulation - I've put her on the detention list.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You mean you're going to invite her in so that she can spill the beans inside the department?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Well, I ... Good point. What do you suggest?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Let me try to get to her. I'll deactivate her.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What does that mean? I don't want to be involved in anything unsavoury.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Trust me. You do trust me, don't you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Of course. We went to school together. You're my oldest friend.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: And you're mine.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You're the only person I can trust.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Then we'd better keep this business just between the two of us.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Right! Just between as and the Security Forces.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: They weren't at school with us.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: But, I've already put her on the search and detain list.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Take her off the list.

Dialogue: There's no procedure for that until she's been arrested.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Say it was a mistake.

Dialogue: We don't make mistakes.

Dialogue: Well, I'd better get out there and try to get to her before security does. Let me borrow her dossier for a while.

Dialogue: Er ... alright. For Christ's sake don't lose it. Here, you'd better sign for it.

Dialogue: Thanks, Jack. I'll be in touch.

Dialogue: Trust me.

Dialogue: You know, smoking's bad for you.
